Authors: Ryan A Ellingson, Patrick J. Krug
Title:
Population-level shifts in larval development mode reduce
genetic diversity and drive reinforcement in a marine gastropod
Keywords:
genetic diversity, lecithotrophy, planktotrophy,
poecilogony, reinforcement, Sacoglossa
Abstract:
Transitions from dispersive to aplanktonic larvae are
predicted to reduce connectivity among, and genetic diversity within,
populations of marine invertebrates. Aplanktonic development may also
lead to outbreeding depression, and/or block hybridization with nearby
planktotrophic populations due to incompatible genetic programs
directing early embryogenesis. However, the rarity of variable
development within species (poecilogony) has precluded population-level
tests, and phylogenetic effects may confound meta-analyses evaluating
these hypotheses among species. Here, we confirm poecilogony in the sea
slug Costasiella ocellifera, and identify consequences of local shifts
to non-dispersive larvae. Most demes expressed planktotrophy and formed
one large Caribbean metapopulation, but four predominantly aplanktonic
populations had reduced genetic diversity and connectivity.
Inter-population crosses revealed post-zygotic isolation between dams
with aplanktonic offspring and sires from other populations, regardless
of genetic or geographic distance, suggesting outbreeding depression.
Neighboring populations also showed strong pre-zygotic isolation,
consistent with reinforcement driven by reduced hatching success of
hybrids. By increasing self-recruitment and the strength of genetic
drift, the loss of dispersal may initiate a feedback loop resulting in
the rapid evolution of reproductive isolation. However, only one
aplanktonic population showed phylogeographic evidence of long-term
persistence; transitions to non-dispersive life histories may thus lead
to population extinction more often than incipient speciation.
